node.title: 4th journalist killed in Mexico in less than a month
node.description: The unprecedented spate of killings has put reporters on edge across Mexico. The government says over 50 journalists have been slain in Mexico since December 2018.
node.content: ["An online news outlet in Mexico said Monday that one of its journalists was shot to death, the fourth journalist to be killed in the country in less than a month.\u00a0Armando Linares, director of the local website Monitor Michoac\u00e1n, said three assailants fatally shot Roberto Toledo in the city of Zitacuaro. Prosecutors in the western state of Michoac\u00e1n said they were investigating the report.\u00a0Linares said the website had received threats for reporting on governmental corruption.\u00a0\"For exposing corrupt administrations and corrupt officials and politicians, today that led to to death of one of our colleagues,\" he said.\u00a0\u00a0\"The Monitor Michoac\u00e1n team has suffered weeks, months of death threats. We know where all of this comes from,\" Linares added, though he did not identify those he thought responsible.\u00a0Jan-Albert Hootsen, the Mexico representative for the Committee to Protect Journalists, said that Toledo worked as a camera operator and video editor for the Monitor Michoac\u00e1n.\u00a0\"We are classifying him as a media worker or press worker,\" Hootsen said.\u00a0Toledo was filming a new video column by Monitor Michoac\u00e1n's deputy director, local lawyer Joel Vera, at Vera's office when the gunmen arrived, the outlet said.\u00a0Jes\u00fas Ram\u00edrez, spokesman for President Andr\u00e9s Manuel L\u00f3pez Obrador, said via Twitter that the administration condemned Toledo's killing.\u00a0\"We will work together with the state and municipal governments to clear up the case,\" Ram\u00edrez wrote. \"We will not allow impunity. We defend freedom of expression and the right to information.\"", "The National Academy of Radio and Television Journalists said in a statement that Toledo and other members of the Monitor Michoac\u00e1n staff had denounced aggression and death threats connected to their work.\u00a0Toledo was enrolled in the federal government's protection system for journalists and human rights defenders known as \"el mecanismo,\" or mechanism, the academy said. It did not say what sort of protection Toledo had received. It can range from carrying a panic button to alert authorities in case of emergency to surveillance cameras installed around a home or even bodyguards.", "The unprecedented spate of killings has put reporters on edge across Mexico, and sparked protests earlier this month. The government says over 50 journalists have been slain in Mexico since December 2018.\u00a0In the border city of Tijuana, two journalists were killed in a week. On January 17, crime photographer Margarito Mart\u00ednez was gunned down outside his home, and on January 23, reporter Lourdes Maldonado L\u00f3pez was found shot to death inside her car.", "\u00a0Reporter Jos\u00e9 Luis Gamboa was killed in the Gulf coast state of Veracruz in an attack on January 10.\u00a0Interior Undersecretary Alejandro Encinas said recently that more than 90% of murders of journalists and rights defenders remain unsolved, despite a government system meant to protect them.\u00a0The New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists puts the percentage at 95%, said Hootsen.", "For Breaking News & Analysis Download the Free CBS News app"]
